author: David Anderson
title: David Haye to undergo potentially-career ending operation on his Achilles after Tony Bellew defeat
text:
David Haye is having surgery on his potentially-career ending Achilles injury. 
Haye has been in hospital since being admitted last night after he bust his ankle during his 11-round stoppage by Tony Bellew . 
Surgeons eventually decided they need to operate to repair the damage and the former two-weight world champ is due to go under the knife later today. 
The Achilles injury could spell the end of Haye's career and he will be sidelined for months while it recovers. 
Haye's pal Carl Froch, who has known him since they were amateurs, fears the injury could end his career. Haye struggles to his feet after being knocked down (Photo: REUTERS) Haye is batted through the ropes (Photo: REUTERS) Haye's ankle twists in the sixth round (Photo: REUTERS) Haye has severe taping on his right leg (Photo: REUTERS) Haye and Bellew embrace after the fight (Photo: REUTERS) 
"We need to see how serious his injury is, but it looked bad and at his age, seeing him fighting again is one thing, but against a top-level heavyweight? I think we can forget it," said the former unified super-middleweight champ. 
"It was a fantastic fight, it really was and although it could be the end of him, you've got to give David Haye credit, because that was clearly a debilitating injury." 
Haye, 36, who fought half the contest on one leg, insists he can recover from the injury and the second stoppage of his career to face Bellew again. 
"I would love to do it again, I have never been in a fight like that," said Haye. "If the fans want to see it again I would do it again. We'll do it on his terms, in his town - he deserves it. 
"I'll get healthy and then, if we would oblige me, we can do it again." 
Haye, who rushed to Munich to see specialist sports doctor Hans Wilhelm Muller-Wohlfahrt before the fight, bravely battled on, throwing hopeful hooks - some of which caught the Bomber, who seemed to gas in the second half of the fight. 
He was then battered through the ropes in the 11th round and despite rising to his feet, trainer Shane McGuigan chucked the towel into the ring with the referee waving the contest off. 
Haye was out of the ring for four years due to a shoulder injury until his comeback last year but now, at 36 years old, faces the toughest battle of his career to return to the ring. 
Victor Bellew revealed after the fight that he also suffered an early injury - when he BROKE his right hand. 
Bellew described his damaged hand as being "the size of a small bowling ball". 
"I broke my right hand in the second or third round," the 34-year-old told BBC Radio 5 Live.
